Description: Vigorously told, excellent drama about the martial arts.
Title: Sugata Sanshirô

Description: Akira Kurosawa's slimmest feature, running only an hour, is also one of the best of his early period.
Title: Tora no o wo fumu otokotachi
Asu o tsukuru hitobito
Directors: Akira Kurosawa, Kajirô Yamamoto, Hideo Sekigawa

Description: It's a 'little people' comedy in the Frank Capra vein
Title: Subarashiki nichiyôbi

Description: Akira Kurosawa's first critical success (1948) is an odd blend of American film noir and Italian neorealism.
Title: Yoidore tenshi

Description: Despite moments of melodrama ... contains a great deal to savor
Title: Shizukanaru kettô

Description: Over the years, this competent but routine if visually effective detective flick has frequently been styled an early gem.
Title: Nora inu

Description: Scandal is not a great film, but it is much more than a curiosity, and much funnier than any plot synopsis might suggest.
Title: Shûbun

Description: One of legendary director Akira Kurosawa's most acclaimed films, Rashomon features an innovative narrative structure, brilliant acting, and a thoughtful exploration of reality versus perception.
Title: Rashômon

Description: Difficult but rewarding drama with outstanding events and location photography of Hokkaido.
Title: Hakuchi

Description: Ikiru is a well-acted and deeply moving humanist tale about a man facing his own mortality, one of legendary director Akira Kurosawa's most intimate films.
Title: Ikiru

Description: Arguably Akira Kurosawa's masterpiece, The Seven Samurai is an epic adventure classic with an engrossing story, memorable characters, and stunning action sequences that make it one of the most influential films ever made.
Title: Shichinin no samurai

Description: Perhaps a bit too loose and leisurely to be entirely effective.
Title: Ikimono no kiroku

Description: A career high point for Akira Kurosawa -- and one of the best film adaptations of a Shakespeare play.
Title: Kumonosu-jô

Description: Essentially a superficial film and that Kurosawa, for all his talent, is as prone to pot-boiling as anyone else.
Title: Kakushi-toride no san-akunin

Description: A well-done thriller with Kurosawa's usual social overtones.
Title: Warui yatsu hodo yoku nemuru

Description: As effortlessly engaging as it is widely influential, Yojimbo represents Kurosawa at the peak of his powers -- and lays the groundwork for the modern American western.
Title: Yôjinbô

Description: Technically impressive and superbly acted, Sanjuro is a funny, action-packed samurai adventure featuring outstanding cinematography and a charismatic performance from Toshiro Mifune.
Title: Tsubaki Sanjûrô

Description: High and Low illuminates its world with a wholeness and complexity you rarely see in film.
Title: Tengoku to jigoku

Description: Akira Kurosawa's Red Beard is assembled with the complexity and depth of a good l9th-century novel, and it is a pleasure, in a time of stylishly fragmented films, to watch a director taking the time to fully develop his characters.
Title: Akahige

Description: The execution is rather crude.
Title: Dodesukaden

Description: Reflects a decline in dramatic power and a doting, futile taste in sentimental hero-worship.
Title: Dersu Uzala

Description: There are great images in this film.
Title: Kagemusha

Description: Akira Kurosawa's sprawling, epic take on King Lear should be required viewing for fans of westerns, war movies, or period films in general.
Title: Ran

Description: In the uneven career of Akira Kurosawa, two limiting factors were sentimentality and preachiness, and both come to the fore in this 1990 collection of eight dreams.
Title: Yume

Description: A beautiful reminder from octogenarian Akira Kurosawa that he's still the master.
Title: Hachigatsu no rapusodî

Description: This is the kind of film we would all like to make, if we were very old and very serene. There were times when I felt uncannily as if Kurosawa were filming his own graceful decline into the night.
Title: Mâdadayo
